Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46227-01  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Developing Procurement Capacity for Improved 
Procurement Outcomes  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
COSO  –  Central Operations Services Office 
DMC  –  developing member country 
OECD  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development  
TA  –  technical assistance 
TASF  –  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Multisector

NOTE  
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Principal Director   S. O’Sullivan, Central Operations Services Office (COSO) 
Director  X. Humbert, Officer-in-Charge, Central Operations Services Division 2 
   
Team leader  J. Pedersen, Procurement Specialist, COSO  
Team member  J. Syquia, Procurement Specialist, COSO 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Public procurement is increasingly being recognized as a tool to improve public service 
delivery and broader development outcomes. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other 
development partners have supported developing member countries (DMCs) to improve their 
public procurement systems since the 1990s. However, inefficient use of funds, continuing 
delays in project implementation, and corruption remain a major concern to governments and 
development partners alike. Through the Paris Declaration, Accra Agenda for Action, and Busan 
Declaration,  ADB  has  committed  to  increasingly  rely  on  country  systems  and  to  support 
procurement capacities in DMCs. 
 
2.   As ADB is considering results-based lending and use of country systems, there is a 
need for ADB to further strengthen its efforts to improve institutional capacity in DMCs and 
mitigate procurement and fiduciary risk within the framework of government-owned programs 
instead of focusing on project-specific and transactional risk mitigation.1 At present, ADB does 
not have a solid framework for engaging with borrowers and sectors that may be eligible for 
results-based financing, and the proposed regional capacity development technical assistance 
(TA) provides a methodology for stepping up institutional procurement capacity. The design and 
monitoring is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.   Efforts to reform DMCs' public procurement have primarily focused on first generation 
reforms at the national level (e.g., legal and regulatory frameworks) and individual staff skills 
enhancement  (by  training  government  officials  engaged  in  procurement).  Although  many 
projects supporting procurement reforms have met their intended targets, a huge task remains 
to  translate  these  into  actual  changes  in  procurement  practices  and  improvements  to 
procurement outcomes.3 
 
4.  The TA will promote a new approach that focuses on ministries or local governments 
(procuring entities4) and other principal participants in the procurement process in key sectors. 
The procuring entities will be determined in cooperation with the national public procurement 
authorities and regional departments. A partnership approach with the procuring entities will be 
implemented to  improve  their  procurement  operations. If  weaknesses  that  prohibit  efficient 
procurement management are found outside the realm of procuring entities, the TA may support 
initiatives to rectify these weaknesses, whether they are institutional or organizational (e.g., in 
national procurement regulatory agencies, supreme audit institutions, the private sector). The 
approach recognizes that procurement capacity development5 is a long-term effort and must 
                                                
1  The policy paper highlights that ―institutional development is the second objective behind the emergence of the 
RBF [results-based financing] approach. … RBF supports building sound institutions and delivering development 
results as two complementary elements of sustainable development.‖ ADB. 2012.  Piloting a Results-Based 
Financing for Programs Modality. Manila. p. 2. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 November 2012. 
3  The Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD-
DAC), through its task force on procurement, has recommended a shift from a focus on compliance to a focus on 
procurement outcomes in the Cusco declaration on procurement: ―Increase focus on performance outcomes to 
drive policies, management and accountability…‖ 
4  Procuring entities are executing and/or implementing agencies that implement ADB-financed projects. The term 
―procuring entity‖ will be used for the purpose of clarity of the TA paper. 
5  Using the OECD-DAC definitions, ―capacity‖ is ―the ability of people, organizations and society as a whole to 
manage successfully their own affairs‖ and ―capacity development‖ is ―processes whereby people, organizations 
and society as a whole unleash, strengthen, create, adapt and maintain capacity over time.‖ OECD. 2006. The 
Challenge of Capacity Development: Working Towards Good Practice. Paris p. 12.

2   
build on procuring entities’ ownership and be tailored to the specific circumstances. The focus 
on individual procuring entities will allow innovative and focused interventions that can yield 
results without major legal or institutional reforms being necessary. The lessons learned and 
results achieved can be replicated in other procuring entities. 
 
5.  Experience from ADB-financed projects across DMCs shows that procurement takes a 
considerable amount of time and is often a source of delay in project implementation.6 ADB 
carries out procurement capacity assessments of procuring entities during project processing to 
detect risk areas and adopt suitable risk mitigation measures during project implementation. 
Risk mitigation is essential to safeguard ADB’s reputation and ensure that ADB financing is 
spent as intended. However, these risk mitigation measures do not aim at developing the long-
term  capacity  of  the  procuring  entity.  The  underlying  causes  of  weak  procurement  and 
implementation capacity, whether they are inherent in the procuring entity or in the environment 
where the procuring entity operates, are not necessarily dealt with. 
 
6.  The causes of weak procurement and implementation capacity in DMCs are not uniform, 
but some common challenges are noticeable. Good organizational practice includes setting 
specific targets on the performance of the agency’s procurement portfolio and continuously 
monitoring  results  to  identify  areas  for  improvement.  This  strategic  approach  to  managing 
procurement  requires  the  appropriate  organizational  setup,  the  right  capabilities  of  and 
incentives for procurement staff, and appropriate systems and internal procedures, which to 
varying degrees are not present in many procuring entities. A procuring entity functions within a 
given  governance  system  and  often  the  procurement  governance  structure  is  weak. 
Procurement audit capacity is often low in government audit institutions, competition authorities 
rarely have the capacity to investigate collusive practices in the private sector, and independent 
complaint mechanisms are either non-existent or not functioning well.7 
 
7.  The private sector is a key player in public procurement. However, in many DMCs 
competition in the private sector for public contracts is limited due to entry barriers, collusive 
practices, or the lack of capacity to meet all requirements in the bidding procedures. Yet both 
the private sector and civil society can play an important role in improving public procurement by 
demanding a more equal and transparent process, with civil society acting as a watchdog in all 
phases of the procurement process, including actual contract implementation. However, the 
private sector and civil society are rarely mobilized in this manner. 
 
8.  The TA will be demand-driven to ensure ownership and commitment from executing 
agencies. For each country and procuring entity supported through the TA a performance and 
monitoring framework will be developed. 
 
9.  The TA is linked to another TA under preparation by ADB's Central Operations Services 
Office (COSO)—TA for Enhancing Capacity for Effective Project Implementation8. Both aim at 
improving  the  implementation  management  of  executing  agencies  of  ADB-funded  projects. 
                                                
6  ADB 2011 Annual Portfolio Performance Review 2011. Manila. 
7  No  comprehensive  comparative  study  exists  covering  DMCs.  However,  a  review  of  country  procurement 
assessment reports and OECD’s methodology for assessing procurement system indicates that while the legal and 
regulatory frameworks are often quite solid, the public procurement market allows limited competition, and 
oversight institutions and actual application of rules are weaker. A proxy indicator for the robustness of public 
procurement systems is how much of donor funds use country procurement systems as defined in the Paris 
Declaration. From 2005 to 2010 the percentage has only improved slightly from 40% to 44% (OECD: Aid 
Effectiveness 2005–2010: Progress in Implementing the Paris Declaration).  
8  ADB 2012. Enhancing Capacity for Effective Project Implementation. Manila (To be approved in December 2012)

3 
However, they intervene at different levels and with different time frames: The TA for Enhancing 
Capacity  Development  for  Project  Implementation  aims  at  building  the  capacity  of  EAs  in 
implementing ADB projects and cover all fields of project implementation. It is therefore a more 
short-term and project-specific capacity development intervention, which continues past efforts 
with a more demand-focused strategy. This TA aims to catalyze reform efforts in a selection of 
progressive and relatively experienced procuring entities to transform government procurement. 
This would allow ADB to rely on the national systems for procurement and to move away from 
prior review. It is therefore a medium- to longer-term capacity development intervention at policy 
and procuring entity level, and is consistent with international moves to use country systems. 
 
10.  Furthermore,  the  TA  builds  on  ADB’s  past  experiences  in  supporting  national 
procurement capacity development through the ongoing TA for the Asia Pacific Procurement 
Partnership Initiative9 as  well  as  country-specific TA  in Indonesia10,  the  Philippines11,  and 
Mongolia12. Such TA support has targeted national policy, national e-procurement systems, 
regional dialogue, and knowledge sharing. A recurrent theme is the lack of procurement metrics 
and quantitative evidence of tangible impact. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impact  of  the  proposed  TA  will  be  to  catalyze  reforms  across  the  region's 
governmental procuring entities that achieve sound country systems and better procurement 
outcomes. 
 
12.  The  outcome  will  be  stronger  strategic  procurement  management  in  participating 
procuring  entities.  The  procuring  entities  will  use  the  procurement  strategy  as  a  tool  to 
continuously improve the procurement function. Each procuring entity will define the targets for 
procurement performance. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Output 1: Comprehensive procurement strategy formulated and implemented.13 
Each procuring entity will devise a comprehensive strategy. Historical and current performance 
levels for each of the participating procuring entities related to cost savings, procurement cycle 
times,  transparency,  and  fairness  will  be  used  to  define  new  performance  targets  for  the 
particular procuring entity.14 Comparisons with international best practices will also be made to 
uncover performance gaps and recognize the most significant opportunities for improvement. To 
achieve its new performance targets the strategy should include recommendations on how to 
(i) optimize procurement staffing; (ii) acquire proper procurement skills through new hiring or 
training; (iii) review and redesign any dysfunctional procurement processes, especially those 
related to specifications development, bid packaging, approvals, record keeping, monitoring,

complaints  resolution,  contract  administration, and  audit;  (iv)  devise  information  technology 
systems that can support the redesigned processes; (v) link staff incentives to achievement of 
new  performance  targets;  (vi)  overcome  financial,  legal,  technological,  cultural,  and  other 
constraints that the procuring entity may face during implementation; (vii) properly sequence the 
implementation  of  various  recommendations;  and  (viii) monitor  and  report  the  strategy 
implementation. The proposed strategy will also recommend how the cross-functional change 
management team can best be equipped to implement the strategy.  
 
14.  Output 2: Key constraints and opportunities in the environment identified. The 
external  environment  has  influence  on  the  procuring  entities’  potential  for  optimizing  their 
procurement. The exact interventions to meet output 2 depend on the country and sector 
conditions but may include analysis of (i) market conditions, (ii) legal and regulatory constraints 
and  weaknesses,  (iii)  possible  improvements  to  procurement  auditing  and  complaints 
mechanisms, and (iv) how best to mobilize of non-state operators to ensure accountability, 
transparency, and monitoring of the procurement process. 
 
15.  Output 3: Lessons from implementing the approach disseminated. For each of the 
selected procuring entities, lessons learned will be disseminated through a knowledge product 
as well as stakeholder workshop within the particular country. In addition, a comparative study 
will be carried out to draw and compare the lessons and best practices from all the selected 
procuring entities. Furthermore, the progress of the procuring entity, including performance 
targets and procurement strategy, will be published.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). However, TA activities will be undertaken 
in any DMC only if such DMC confirms its no objection to such TA participation. Detailed cost 
estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency. COSO will be responsible for all TA activities. The TA 
will  be  implemented  from  January  2013  to  July  2016.  Implementing  agencies  will  be  the 
selected procuring entities and/or the national procurement authorities. COSO will work closely 
and agree with the relevant regional departments on proposals for support under the TA.  
 
18.  The TA will require international consultants (estimated 40 person-months) and national 
consultants (estimated 100 person-months) with skills in procurement management, change 
management, and capacity development. Individual terms of reference will be developed for 
each  subproject  under  the  TA.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  either  through  a  firm  or  as 
individuals. ADB will recruit all consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010 as amended from time to time). All equipment will be purchased following 
ADB Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the 
TA will be done in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).

5 
19.  Discussions  with  regional  departments  have  generated  interest  from  Bangladesh, 
Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam.15 It is proposed that the TA will initially focus on these 
countries. The following criteria will be used in determining whether a procuring entity is eligible 
for support under the TA: 
(i)  The  government  has  implemented  (or  is  implementing)  first-generation 
procurement  reforms  and  the  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  support  the 
principles  of  public  procurement,  including  open  competition,  transparency, 
accountability, and value for money. 
(ii)  The procuring entity and ADB have a long-term relationship and the procuring 
entity will implement ADB-financed projects in the foreseeable future. 
(iii)  The procuring entity’s senior management is supportive and takes ownership of 
efforts to improve transparency and accountability in the procurement process 
with the aim of improving procurement outcomes. 
 
20.  Resident missions will, in consultation with relevant sector divisions and the COSO 
country focal point, submit for COSO review (i) a brief proposal outlining the scope and the 
participating procuring entity, (ii) confirmation of the government’s request for ADB support, 
(iii) detailed terms of reference for the consultants, and (iv) a detailed budget.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Developing Procurement Capacity for Improved Procurement Outcomes, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
 
 
                                                
15 Afghanistan,  Nepal,  Papua  New  Guinea,  the  Philippines,  and  Uzbekistan  are  other  countries  that  regional 
departments have suggested for possible inclusion in the TA. COSO will assess the demand from DMCs, regional 
departments and resident missions and if warranted seek additional funds from development partners.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  All consultants will be recruited in accordance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  approximately  40  person-months  of 
international and 100 person-months of national consulting services. The terms of reference and 
inputs will be further developed once the participating procuring entities have been selected. 
 
3.  Strategic procurement advisors (international, four advisors, about 8 person-months 
each). For each of the participating procuring entities, strategic procurement advisors will be 
recruited to analyze the procurement function of the procuring entity, assist in developing a 
comprehensive  procurement  strategy,  and  advise  on  the  implementation  of  the  strategy. 
Specifically the advisors will: 
(i)  analyze the procurement spend of the procuring entity and develop procurement 
benchmarks and monitoring framework for the different procurement categories; 
(ii)  carry out a supply market analysis of the key markets; 
(iii)  based on the spend profile of the procuring entity, develop a comprehensive draft 
procurement strategy taking into account the supply markets and the regulatory 
framework(s) under which the procuring entity operates,  
(iv)  advise the procuring entity on implementation of the procurement strategy, assist 
in monitoring progress, and advise on corrective actions; 
(v)  analyze the enabling environment in which the procuring entity operates and 
advise on how to address constraints; and 
(vi)  present and evaluate lessons learned both at midterm and at the end of the TA. 
 
4.  The advisors will have a postgraduate degree in a relevant field and should preferably 
have 15 years of experience advising public sector organizations in procurement management, 
and  have  experience  in  procurement  spend  profiling,  category  management,  capacity 
development,  and  change  management.  Furthermore,  the  advisors  should  preferably  have 
experience in the sector of the participating procuring entity. 
 
5.  Short-term procurement advisors (international, four advisors, about 2 person-months 
each). For each of the participating procuring entities, short-term advisors may be needed to 
assist the strategic procurement advisors in specific tasks. The short-term advisors may include 
contract specialists, e-procurement specialists, or organizational development specialists as 
needed.  All  short-term  advisors  will  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  a  relevant  field  and 
preferably 10 years of experience in advising public sector organizations. 
 
6.  Procurement specialists (national, four specialists, about 25 person-months each). For 
each of the participating procuring entities, national procurement specialists will support the 
strategic procurement advisors in all tasks. Specifically the national specialists will: 
(i)  under the direction of the strategic procurement advisor, carry out the spend 
profile, and, in cooperation with procuring entity counterpart staff, collect and 
analyze data; 
(ii)  carry out supply market analysis under the guidance of the strategic procurement 
advisor; 
(iii)  gather data for procurement benchmarking and for the procurement monitoring 
system; 
(iv)  work with procuring entity counterpart staff in  implementing the procurement 
strategy; and

(v)  assist the  strategic  procurement  advisor  in capturing  and  evaluating  lessons 
learned. 
 
7.  The  national  specialists  will  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  a  relevant  field  and 
preferably 10 years of experience in advising public or private sector organizations on strategic 
procurement, spend management, and sourcing strategies. The national specialists should also 
be familiar with the sector and the regulatory framework(s) under which the procuring entity 
operates.
